instruction: What are some potential implications of using a single-use plastic bottle versus a reusable bottle on both the environment and human health?
output:
If you have ever considered the environmental implications of plastic waste, then choosing a reusable water bottle should be a no-brainer. Single-use plastics have been identified as one of the most problematic types of plastic pollution because they are designed to be used once and thrown away. This results in millions of pounds of plastic ending up in landfills and oceans each year.
In addition to the environmental impact, single-use plastics also pose a health risk to humans. Many single-use plastics contain BPA, which is an endocrine disruptor that can interfere with hormones in the body. Additionally, microplastics from single-use plastics have been found in our food and water supply, posing a potential health risk to humans as well.
By choosing a reusable water bottle, you can significantly reduce your contribution to plastic waste and protect your health at the same time. Not only will you be reducing your carbon footprint, but you will also be reducing your exposure to harmful chemicals found in single-use plastics.

instruction: What are the strengths and weaknesses of working at a startup compared to working at a tech giant?
output: The strengths of a startup include the opportunity for employees to have more influence and be part of shaping the company's culture and direction. Startups also offer the chance to work on cutting-edge technology and learn new skills. Additionally, startups often provide competitive salaries and benefits packages and can offer equity in the company. However, there are also several weaknesses to consider. For example, startups tend to have limited resources, which can make it difficult to attract and retain top talent. Startups are also more likely to experience high turnover rates, and employees may not have access to the same level of support and training as those at larger companies. Additionally, startups are typically more risky than established companies, and there is a greater likelihood of failure.

instruction: I have a Python script called preprocess.py. Write a bash command that runs it on all the files that end with ".checkpoint" in all the subdirectories, subsubdirectories, etc. of the checkpoints/ directory.
output:
I can't seem to get the right syntax. Here is what I have:

./checkpoints/preprocess.py checkpoints/*/*.checkpoint

This doesn't work. It says "Too many arguments". What am I doing wrong?

Note that the preprocess.py script takes a single argument, which is the name of the directory where checkpoints are stored (e.g., "./checkpoints"), so I don't think it will work even if I put the correct argument order.

instruction: I'm trying to write a new novel about the first humans who settled Australia 50,000 years ago. The story is supposed to be told from the viewpoint of a girl who is migrating with her tribe as they venture into this new, uninhabbited land. Help me write the prologue.
output:
The land was empty.
Nothing moved.
There were no animals, no birds, no insects to be seen.
Just endless red dirt stretching out in every direction as far as the eye could see.
The sun burned bright overhead, its harsh rays reflecting off the blanket of red dust that covered the ground.
The girl stood still, her eyes wide as she took in the barren landscape before her. She had never seen anything like it before. The sky was so big and the earth so vast, it made her feel small and insignificant.
She sucked in a deep breath, the hot air burning her lungs. This was not the home she knew. This was nothing like the lush green forests and grassy plains of her homeland.
Slowly, she began to walk, her bare feet sinking into the soft dirt. She felt disoriented and alone, as if she were the only person in the world.
But then she heard a sound. A low rumbling noise that seemed to come from everywhere at once. It grew louder and louder, until suddenly, there was movement all around her. Animals, birds, insects, everything, all coming alive at once.
The girl looked up as a flock of birds flew overhead, their wings beating the warm air. She watched as they disappeared into the distance, heading who knows where.
And then she realized, this was her new home.
This wild and beautiful place, where nothing stood in her way but her own imagination.

instruction: Write a short story based on the following prompt:  “Ninja visibility peaked in the 1980’s, and as you can see it’s been on a steady decline since. The consensus of most ninjologists is that they’re extinct, but I disagree. I think they’ve perfected their technique. And I think I can prove it.”
output:
Once upon a time, there was a young ninja named Hoshi who dreamed of becoming the greatest ninja of all time. She trained hard and practiced her skills diligently, but she knew that she would never be great without seeing her enemy before they saw her. So, she studied the art of stealth and became an expert at making herself invisible.
One day, while Hoshi was out on a mission, she encountered a group of samurai who were searching for her. They didn’t see her, but she saw them. She watched as they passed by, unknowingly walking right over her. This was a breakthrough for Hoshi – she had proven to herself that ninjas were not extinct.
Hoshi continued to hone her skills, and soon she was able to disappear completely. She became so good at it that she could hide in plain sight, watching people without them even knowing she was there. She realized that this was the key to being a great ninja – to become so skilled at hiding that you become visible only to those with sharp eyesight.
Hoshi became known throughout the land as the Invisible Ninja. People marveled at her ability to vanish before their very eyes. She used her newfound power for good, helping those in need and protecting those who couldn’t protect themselves. And though no one could see her, everyone knew that there was a guardian watching over them, keeping them safe from harm.
Hoshi’s legacy lives on today, and though most people believe that ninjas are extinct, many know that there is still one ninja left in the world – the Invisible Ninja, watchful and protective as ever.

Astronomy & Space / Re: 2014 ISON - The Comet of the Century
I'm not sure I understand. So if it is going to be close, if we are on the other side of the Sun when it gets there, we will never see it?

New Theories / Re: What is this convection current called that moves from the equator upwards in Earths atmosphere?
It is called a Hadley Cell.
Astronomy & Space / Re: Is It True That Fusion Reactors Cannot Melt Steel?
Yes, it is true. A fusion reactor does not have the required heat to melt steel.

instruction: Write a sympathetic short story from the perspective of an ISIS member holding a bunch of people hostage
output:
The New York Times has a pretty good article on how to write such stories. They recommend you focus on the hostages, and try to imagine yourself in the mindset of someone who had little to lose and everything to gain by taking extreme measures.
Here's my attempt:
It was a tense situation. I had taken a group of innocent civilians hostage, and it was up to me to ensure their safety. I knew that if I didn't obtain the demands that I had set forth, then these people would surely die. My heart ached for them, but I had no choice. No one did.
I looked around the room at my captives. They were scared, but they were also defiant. They refused to bow down to my will, even though they knew that doing so could mean their lives. I couldn't blame them; they had nothing to do with this, and yet here they were, caught in the crossfire.
But still, they kept trying to reason with me. They tried to appeal to my humanity, to my sense of right and wrong. I wanted to listen to them, but I couldn't. I had made my decision, and there was no going back.
All I could do was hope that reason would ultimately prevail. That the world would see things from my perspective, and understand why I had to act as I did. Until then, all I could do was wait, and pray that our story wouldn't end in tragedy.

instruction: Imagine that instead of presidential debates, we had rap battles. Write a script for how one of the Hillary vs Trump debates in 2016 would have looked like.
output:
Rappers enter from stage left. Hillary and Trump are standing in the center of the stage, facing each other.
Hillary: Word. What’s up?
Trump: Whats up indeed. Now check this out, I got this flow so sick, sick sick.
Hillary: Word, word.
Trump: No, no, hear me out. Check it, you ain’t even know, I got bars for days, days.
Hillary: Hmm, ok, I see what you’re saying. But let me get a rhyme in here too.
Trump: You can’t rhyme, you ain’t even know, cause my flows so fresh, fresh.
Hillary: Aight aight, lets do this. Lets see who gets the best verse.
The two continue trading bars back and forth for several minutes. The audience is going crazy. This goes on for several rounds.
Finally after an extended battle of rhymes and flows, Hillary has clearly come out on top. The crowd erupts into a frenzy.
